description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: March 11, 2020: With Bulletin N. 107, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health participated in a meeting with Health Ministers of other European countries including Austria, Denmark, France, Germany, The Netherlands, Poland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and UK. During the conference call, each State provided an update on the local epidemiological situation and outlined the measures adopted to fight the COVID-19 emergency.

description: Denmark is reopening its previously closed schools for pupils from pre-school through fifth grades and from classes for pupils with special needs. Before- and after-school care (for pupils up to the fifth grade) will open at the same time. Older pupils are continuously taught digitally at home. UPDATE: Schools reopen for pupils from pre-school through fifth grades and for classes for pupils with special needs from all grade. Before- and after-school care (for pupils up to the fifth grade) will open at the same time. Exceptions e.g. for health concerns apply.

This means the oldest school children, from ages 16, can return to school before the summer holiday. However, students in the last year of high-school will not return to school. Evening, music and cultural schools, scouts, as well as outdoor amusement parks and summer activities for children and young people can also reopen.

description: As of Monday, 9 November 2020, students at institutions of higher education in the affected municipalities will move to online teaching and have exams not requiring physical attendance. description: The Danish Prime Minister imposed a partial lockdown in 38 municipalities from December 9, 2020, to January 3, 2021. description: Effective March 1, 2021 Schools will be allowed to partially reopen in some areas of the country, but not in others. Final year students at elementary schools, upper secondary schools and further education (not universities) can now physically attend classes in North Jutland and West Jutland. Classes will return at 50 percent capacity, meaning that students will attend every other week. At elementary schools, students over the age of 12 will be asked to take a Covid-19 test twice weekly but it will not be mandatory. However, students at the other education types will not be allowed to attend without taking a test."

description: On December 30, 2020, the Danish Health Ministry amended an order that COVID-19 Vaccines will be provided free of charge to all residing in Denmark and those entitled to vaccination benenfits under EU Law or other international agreements. Excluded are children under 16 and those pregnant or breastfeeding must receive a doctors recommendation. Amendment also clarifies that vaccinations can only be distributed to regional hospital pharmacies, which will run distribution to other facilities within each of the regions.

help

- Personnel in the health, elderly and selected parts of the social sector at particular risk of infection, or who carry out a critical function.
- Selected persons with conditions and diseases which entail a particularly increased risk of severe course of COVID-19
- Selected relatives of persons with a particularly increased risk of a serious course or relatives who are an indispensable care or care person
- Persons aged 80-84 years
- Persons aged 75-79 years
- Persons aged 65-74 years
- People under the age of 65 who have conditions and illnesses that lead to an increased risk of a serious course of COVID-19
- Personnel who carry out other socially critical functions
- Other population, e.g. segmented by age

description: According to the official calendar, up to the current date the Danish Health Authority has determined that the target groups for the vaccination programme should be given priority in the following order: Residents in nursing homes and people aged 65 years or older who receive both personal care and practical assistance; Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society; Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19; Selected relatives of persons at significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as carers.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On March 13 2020, the Government of Denmark is effectively closing its borders to all but Danish citizens and individuals with Danish work or residency permits. Danes are further strongly advised against leaving the country, and all other countries have been categorized as orange. 
All non-residents will be required to present a "noteworthy purpose" for entering the country and if their purpose is not satisfactory, their entry will be declined and they will be "asked to return to their country of departure".
The closure of the external borders have been set to last until April 13 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From May 25 2020, people with a permanent residence in one of the five Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden) or Germany will be allowed to re-enter Denmark if they fall into the following categories:
People who own a summer house in Denmark
Persons who have a relationship with a person living in Denmark or who are engaged to a person living in Denmark
People who have grandparents in Denmark
Business trips to and from Denmark if they are carried out responsibly in terms of health, may be resumed if the applicable precautionary measures are followed. Business trips must comply with industry-specific security precautions.
Except for the above, general family visits, tourism trips, business trips, study trips or similar are not grounds for entry into Denmark that are worthy of recognition.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: As part of the agreement of 20 May 2020 on a further re-opening in phase 2, a series of guidelines and specific travel advice was issued to facilitate necessary international business travel to and from Denmark, while continuing to observe sound health precautions. In recognition of the responsibility of businesses to prevent the spread of COVID-19, the advice for business travel recommends that businesses adopt a precautionary approach. First and foremost, this means assessing the necessity of travel on a case-by-case basis. Second, to follow the advice for business travel to minimize the risk that employees become infected with novel coronavirus COVID-19 while abroad.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On June 10, 2020 it was announced that On Monday 15 June, the Faroe Islands will reopen to visitors from Denmark, Greenland, Iceland, Norway and Germany. Travel from other destinations remains limited to Faroese residents returning home, and people travelling for work in the Faroe Islands.
Travelers from Denmark, Greenland, Iceland, Norway and Germany should present proof of a negative COVID-19 test that has been taken within the last five days. Faroese residents are not required to be tested prior to returning.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
On 29 May 2020, the Danish Prime Minister announced that border restrictions will be lifted from June 15 for tourists from Germany, Iceland and Norway that have booked a stay of minimum six nights outside of Copenhagen and Frederiksberg. 

The Danish borders remain closed to all but these groups, Danish citizens, individuals with Danish work or residency permits, and those the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel. UPDATE: Border closures extended to August 31. The Danish border closure - imposed on March 14 and scheduled to be in effect until June 1 - was extended to August 31.  This ban applies to all foreign tourists coming to Denmark, except for those permanently living in Germany, Norway, and Iceland who - effective June 15 - will be permitted to enter Denmark if they have a lodging reservation outside of the Copenhagen region for six nights or more. UPDATE: The original policy imposed on March 14 and scheduled to be in effect until June 1 - was extended to August 31.

description:
The government of Denmark is enforcing a restriction of external borders: Denmark closed its borders to all but Danish citizens, individuals with Danish work or residency permits, and those the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel after March 14. The closures will be in effect until April 13. UPDATE: From May 25, people with a permanent residence in one of the five Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden) or Germany will be allowed to re-enter Denmark if they fall into the following categories:
People who own a summer house in Denmark
Persons who have a relationship with a person living in Denmark or who are engaged to a person living in Denmark
People who have grandparents in Denmark
Business trips to and from Denmark if they are carried out responsibly in terms of health, may be resumed if the applicable precautionary measures are followed. Business trips must comply with industry-specific security precautions. UPDATE: The external border restriction in place since March 14 will be lifted for tourists from Germany, Iceland and Norway from June 15.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

The Danish borders remain closed to all but these groups, Danish citizens, individuals with Danish work or residency permits, and those the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel UPDATE: Effective 27 June, the Danish Government will implement a new model for opening the borders and easing travel advice for countries in the EU and Schengen area, as well as the UK. The model establishes a number of objective criteria, including a low number of infected persons, which will determine the countries for which the borders will be opened.

description:
On Thursday, 2 July, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark will implement a new travel advice model for countries outside of the EU/Schengen and UK (also known as “third countries”). The travel advice will be eased for countries that both meet the EU’s new COVID-19 criteria for entry into the EU and do not have significant entry restrictions or quarantine requirements for incoming Danish travellers.

The model for opening the borders and easing travel advice for countries in the EU, the Schengen area and the UK is still in place since the 27 June.

description: Many Danish seafarers are currently stranded on ships all over the world because the COVID-19 pandemic prevents them from making crew changes. After discussions with the industry, the government is therefore now presenting a solution so that seafarers can get ashore safely. The new scheme ensures that seafarers who need it can obtain a visa to enter or leave Denmark under controlled conditions so that they can either get off or on ships at home or in other countries. Denmark will be ready to receive the seafarers under the temporary scheme within 14 days valid from 20 July.

UPDATE: As regards entry into Denmark, as of Saturday 31 October 2020 at 00:00, persons residing in all EU, Schengen and UK countries, with the exception of Estonia, Finland and Norway and certain regions of Sweden, will require a recognised purpose of entry into Denmark. This means that these countries and regions will be considered "open" for the purposes of the entry rules. It should be noted that residents of 'high risk' countries entering Denmark for a recognizable purpose must present a negative COVID-19 test taken at least 72 hours before the time of entry. Read more about the testing requirement, including the exceptions, and current 'high risk' countries at the National Police. UPDATE: Now all countries except Estonia, Finland, Norway and some regions of Sweeden are targeted for the policy regarding entry rules.

description:
Effective on November 5, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark advises against all non-essential travel to virtually all countries within the EU/Schengen and the UK. Estonia (36.2) and Norway (39.2) are added to the list of countries where all non-essential travel is advised against due to excessive numbers of infected people, based on the figures from the SSI. The Vatican is removed from the list and changed to yellow (be extra cautious) due to a low infection rate. 
Finland continues to meet the low infection criterion, but due to entry restrictions on travelers from Denmark, all non-essential travel is advised against.

description: As far as entry into Denmark is concerned, from Saturday 28 November 2020 at 00.00 require a recognizable purpose to enter Denmark for persons residing in all countries of the EU, Schengen, and the United Kingdom with the exception of the Vatican City State and parts of Finland, although special rules apply for the border country. Persons residing in high-risk countries traveling into Denmark with a recognizable purpose must be able to present a negative COVID-19 test performed a maximum of 72 hours before the time of entry.

description: From November 11, 2020 Denmark adopts a new guideline. A regional approach to travel guides is being introduced today in the EU and Schengen countries, as well as the United Kingdom.  At the same time, the health authorities' new main recommendation enters into force. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs updates the travel guides for the EU and the Schengen countries as well as the United Kingdom on a weekly basis on the basis of the latest infection figures from the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control  ECDC . For those countries that provide regional test data to ECDC, it will be possible to open for travel to low-risk regions in quarantine countries. Travel to high-risk regions in open countries may also be discouraged. In addition, all unnecessary travel to countries with significant entry restrictions is discouraged for travelers from Denmark. The assessment of whether a country or region is open or quarantined also includes a number of technical criteria regarding test frequency, positive percentage and data availability.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: Effective from December 18, 2020 : The Ministry of Foreign Affairs' travel guides for third countries are updated on the basis of the EU's list of countries outside the EU and Schengen area, which may be considered for the opening because they meet established COVID-19 criteria for entry into the EU. The result of the EU's latest review of the country list means that Uruguay is being removed from the list due to rising infection. The EU list includes the following countries: Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand. However, all the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' travel guides for the countries on the EU list remain orange (all unnecessary travel is not recommended). This is either because the countries in question have introduced entry restrictions for Danish travelers, or because the Danish authorities consider that, based on a precautionary principle, it is not possible to open for health reasons

description:
Denmark extends stricter entry restrictions for foreigners residing in the United Kingdom : 

In light of the proliferation of a new mutation of COVID-19, the government introduced stricter entry restrictions for UK residents from 25 December 2020 to 3 January 2021. The stricter restrictions mean that aliens residing in the UK as the clear starting point is denied entry into Denmark.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On December 22, 2020 it was announced that the Danish government introduced stricter entry restrictions for foreigners residing in the UK. This means that foreigners residing in Great Britain will be refused entry if they wish to enter Denmark.

However, the following groups of people from Great Britain are exempt and can still enter Denmark:

Is the primary caregiver for minor children (must present a negative COVID-19 test taken no later than 72 hours before the time of entry.)
Are relatives or loved ones of seriously ill or dying persons in Denmark (must present a negative COVID-19 test carried out no later than 72 hours before the time of entry.)
Entry for the purpose of freight transport
Danish citizens and persons with residence in Denmark who are in Great Britain will still be able to enter Denmark. However, there will be a strong call for Danes returning home from the UK to get tested on entry and to self-isolate for 10 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 1 January 2021, the United Kingdom will no longer be covered by the Danish model for entry restrictions and travel guides for EU and Schengen countries. Instead, the United Kingdom will be included in the Danish model for entry restrictions and travel guides for third countries. The change is due to the fact that the UK, due to Brexit, will be considered a third country in relation to EU law per. January 1, 2021, when the transitional arrangement expires.

description: Initially, the Government introduced stricter requirements for persons entering Denmark from the border regions, including Schleswig-Holstein, southern Sweden (the provinces of Blekinge and Scania), and western Sweden (the provinces of Halland and West Gothia). This entails that persons who enter Denmark with a worthy purpose must be able to present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry. Under the rules applicable so far, the test must have been taken no more than seven days before entry.

description:
On May 12, 2020 it was announced that The government published more details about the new test strategy. The strategy now contains two "tracks" for testing:
-Track 1 (“the health care track”): testing of referred citizens with COVID-19 symptoms, citizens in hospitals and health care personnel (this track is organized by the five regions)
-Track 2: ("the societal track"): testing of asymptomatic "close contacts", citizens selected for random sample testing, social care personnel, etc. This track is organized by national authorities and takes place in temporary COVID-19 test facilities in 16 locations throughout the country.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
The government of Denmark establishes a new Returning Agency.
The government has a goal that more foreigners without legal residence must travel home. That is why the Ministry of Immigration and Integration is now establishing a new Home Travel Agency. The order is effective from the 15th of April 2020. The new board takes over most of its tasks on 1 August 2020 and will be responsible for more foreigners without legal residence traveling home. Today there are approximate. 1,100 rejected asylum seekers in Denmark.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective from June 22, 2020. The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration is granted powers of supervision over herds when they are confirmed to be infected with covid-19. These powers include 1) killing of the herd 2) no additions or removals from the herd 3) notification of anyone who was in contact with the herd 4) proper handling of animals (dead and alive), equipment, feed, etc. that was in contact with confirmed cases.

description: Several municipalities in Denmark invest heavily in improving cycling paths while discouraging the use of public transport to slow the spread of the virus.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_text: The policy is more intended as a recommendation not to use public transport. There is an economic factor to the policy regarding the government's investment in cycle paths, which perhaps makes it an 'economic' policy. Thus, I'm correcting the policy to 'other'.

description: Denmark is promoting free vaccines for the over-65s and vulnerable groups under 65 (pneumococci), health workers and vulnerable groups (flu) and pregnant women (whooping cough). The goal is to reach a 75 percent sign-up rate for the pneumococci and flu vaccinations. This goes into effect on April 22.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Denmark is giving out new guidelines for professions with close contact with infected or potentially infected people (especially in the health and care sectors) from April 24 2020 on. The key point is mandatory protective gear.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: Denmark is giving out new guidelines for professions with close contact with infected or potentially infected people (especially in the health and care sectors) from April 24 on. The key point is mandatory protective gear.

description: On August 25, 2020 it was announced that starting August 8, 2020 Denmark Amends and extends requirement that Laboratories that detect SARS-CoV-2 or antibodies in sample material from patients must report the result of the sample to the Statens Serum Institute. Additionally extends the requirement that physicians that treat cases are required to inform the institute with details about the case upon request. Amendment adds stipulation that now requires labs that detect covid-19 to share a sample to the Statens Serum Institute.

description: On January 13, 2021 it was announced that Denmark Ends healthcare professional's obligation to notify the Danish Agency for Patient Safety of any information, including patient records, relevant to a decision on the initiation of compulsory medical treatment - more decision making ability regarding what is pertinent information is granted to healthcare professionals.

description: On February 3, 2021 it was announced that The Danish Agency for Patient Safety may arrange a forensic autopsy of persons who have passed away within 7 days of receiving of a covid-19 vaccine, if the Agency deems that an autopsy is necessary to clarify whether the deaths are related to the vaccination.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
On 21 April 2021, new coronapa (PASSPORT) rules came into effect, where people who have previously been infected are now considered immune for 14-180 days after a positive test.
The Corona passport can be used as documentation for whether a citizen is, respectively:

Fully vaccinated
Tested negative within 72 hours (both PCR and antigen test)
Immune due to a past infection with Covid-19

description: Denmark is ordering home quarantine for all infected people that have no or mild symptoms and are not considered particularly vulnerable are placed with daily contact from health professionals. Anybody that has been in close contact with someone who is known to be infected by SARS-CoV-2 is placed in home quarantine as well. Quarantine in those cases is enforced for 14 days. The policy was announced on 29 February 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Denmark is ordering home quarantine for all infected people that have no or mild symptoms and are not considered particularly vulnerable are placed with daily contact from health professionals. Anybody that has been in close contact with someone who is known to be infected by SARS-CoV-2 is placed in home quarantine as well. Quarantine in those cases is enforced for 14 days. The policy was announced on 29 February 2020. UPDATE: The original quarantine for those in close contact with someone infected by the virus was 14 days, it has been changed so that these people should self-isolate until they have received 2 negative COVID-19 tests results. These should be submitted/taken om the 4th and 6th day of isolation, and once these have been verified, the person can exit their self-isolation.

All countries but Germany, Iceland and Norway remain orange, which means that passengers entering Denmark from all other countries but these three are strongly encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival. UPDATE: The list of countries from where travelers are encouraged to self-isolate upon arrival to Denmark was updated on the 27th of June 2020 and a new policy was introduced - separating EU/Schengen (and UK) countries from the rest of the world. This means that all travelers from outside the EU/Schengen (and UK) are still strongly encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days, whilst the restrictions/recommendations for travelers from a EU/Schengen (and UK) country will depend on the level of contamination in said country, which will be updated on a weekly basis by Statens Serum Institut and Udenrigsministeriet.

description:
Danish authorities announced on June 18 that the country will introduce a new regional model for their travel restrictions/recommendations for the EU and Schengen (and UK) countries.
Effective June 27, EU and Schengen countries will be categorized as either open/yellow (åbent) or quarantine country/orange (karantæneland) depending on its level of coronavirus spread. 
To be categorized as yellow, the country needs to report a level of under 20 infected citizens/ 100 000 citizens. 
An orange is those that report a level of 30 infected citizens /100 000 citizens or higher, and for travelers entering Denmark from a quarantine country, the Danish authorities strongly encourage a self-isolation period of 14 days. 
The list of orange countries will be updated on a weekly basis as of June 27 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

Effective on stated date, travelers from Portugal, Sweden, Bulgaria and Luxembourg are encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival to Denmark.

description: In response to the spread of COVID-19 in the country's mink farms, Denmark presents new guidelines and recommendations for residents in the following seven municipalities; Hjørring, Frederikshavn, Brønderslev, Jammerbugt, Vesthimmerland, Thisted and Læsø. As of the 9th of November, the Health Ministry is encouraging all those who work or live with someone who works at a mink farm with verified spread of the virus to stay at home and self-isolate until the contaminated livestock has been terminated and removed from site.

description:
Danish authorities announced on June 18 that the country will introduce a new regional model for their travel restrictions/recommendations for the EU and Schengen (and UK) countries.
Effective June 27, EU and Schengen countries will be categorized as either open/yellow (åbent) or quarantine country/orange (karantæneland) depending on its level of coronavirus spread. 
To be categorized as yellow, the country needs to report a level of under 20 infected citizens/ 100 000 citizens. 
An orange is those that report a level of 30 infected citizens /100 000 citizens or higher, and for travelers entering Denmark from a quarantine country, the Danish authorities strongly encourage a self-isolation period of 14 days. 
The list of orange countries will be updated on a weekly basis as of June 27 2020. UPDATE: As of December 12 2020, Danish authorities will provide travelers with more detailed travel restrictions/recommendations as regions inside an orange/yellow country can be classified as low vs high risk, which in practice thus allows traveling to yellow regions in orange countries.
The recommendations for travelers returning/entering Denmark from an orange country or region has also changed, from 14 days to 10 days of self-isolation, which can be ended at the 5th day on providing a negative Covid-19 test result.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: As of the 21st of December 2020, Denmark is encouraging all passengers traveling from the UK to self-isolate for 10 days or until they have received a negative test result 4 days upon entering the country. If the traveler has been in close contact with any other persons upon arriving in Denmark, these people should also take COVID-19 tests to ensure that the new virus variant does not enter the country.

description: Danish authorities updated their travel restrictions/recommendations on January 8 2021. Based on an assessment of the global rate of coronavirus spread, all countries are categorized as red, which in practice means that Danish authorities are discouraging all travel outside of the country's borders and that everyone entering Denmark should self-isolate for 10 days, an isolation that can be broken on the 5th day upon providing a negative PCR test. The policy is in effect as of January 8 and has been given a preliminary end date of January 17 2021.

description:

The isolation can be ended on the 4th day of isolation is the person has submitted a negative PCR test on that day.  UPDATE: From 21 April, entry from the following countries/regions of the EU and Schengen countries will be opened: Iceland (the whole country), Norwegian regions: Nordland, Trøndelag, Troms and Finnmark.
It will be possible to enter into Denmark from these countries/regions from 21 April without any requirement for worthy purposes, just as travellers from these countries/regions will be exempted from the isolation requirement after entry. As a result of national reviews of the EU country list, travellers from the following third countries may enter into Denmark from 21 April: Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand. All persons entering Denmark from a country placed on the yellow list will be exempt from the isolation requirements. Travellers from countries and regions that are categorized as orange have to go self-isolation after the entry. UPDATE: Target of the policy has changed. The original policy was set for all countries, however countries labelled as yellow among EU schengen area and covid safe areas among third countries now can be exempted from entry restrictions.

description: From the 1st of May 2021, people who are residents in Denmark or in orange countries of the EU/Schengen area are exempt from requiring a test or needing to self-isolate on returning to Denmark. However, children aged 15 to 17 years must continue to be tested after entering Denmark. People who have not previously been infected and vaccinated have to go self-isolation after the entry. UPDATE : The requirement for people entering Denmark to have a worthy purpose for their visit is being discontinued for all foreigners residing in orange EU and Schengen countries. This means that tourists from EU and Schengen countries, among others, will be also able to enter Denmark. They will still be subject to post-entry testing and isolation requirements unless they are vaccinated or have been previously infected. The isolation requirement will lapse on 26 June (phase 4) for persons entering Denmark from orange EU and Schengen countries. UPDATE: The original policy only targeted the residents of Denmark and EU/Schengen Countries. The demographic target has changed to all residents and travellers from these countries

description: From the 10th of June in Denmark people who are fully vaccinated or previously infected with a new coronavirus (except in cases where it is a particularly contagious variant ) and have contacted infected people do not need to go to self-isolation. However, should get tested on the 4th and 6th day after the last close contact with the infected person. If there are symptoms of COVID-19, those people still go for self-isolation. People who are not vaccinated or previously infected still have to go to 10 days of self-isolation.

description: From the 10th of June in Denmark people who are fully vaccinated or previously infected with a new coronavirus (except in cases where it is a particularly contagious variant ) and have contacted infected people do not need to go to self-isolation. However, should get tested on the 4th and 6th day after the last close contact with the infected person. If there are symptoms of COVID-19, those people still go for self-isolation. People who are not vaccinated or previously infected still have to go to 10 days of self-isolation. UPDATE:The updated guidelines recommend that in connection with each case of infection, detection of close contacts and close contacts of the close contacts is now initiated. There is no longer a distinction between which variant of virus you are infected with. In the revised version, close contacts must continue to go in self-insulation and be tested twice, while the close contacts of the close contacts can be content with testing and do not have to self-insulate. UPDATE: The original policy targeted everyone in close contact with infected people. A new plan is initiated that changes the target of the policy

description: According to the update which entered into force on September 4, Denmark requires travelers who have not been fully vaccinated or previously infected with the virus arriving from the US, Israel, Kosovo, Lebanon, Montenegro, and North Macedonia, among orange countries of EU/Schengen region, to undergo COVID-19 testing before and stay self-isolated for ten days. UPDATE: The decision has been announced by the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which updated the list of restrictions on  10th of September 2021, noted that the following six countries have now been removed from the green list of the Danish authorities, to the orange one:Albania,Armenia,Azerbaijan,Brunei Darussalam,Japan,Serbia. The change means that travellers reaching Denmark from these countries must be vaccinated in order to be eligible to enter. Those who have recovered from the Coronavirus in recent months are also eligible to enter. Upon arrival to Denmark, the same must also undergo a second test after entry and stay self-isolated for ten days. The previous decision made for the traveller arriving from U.S and Israel is still in place as these countries in the orange list. UPDATE: Demographic target of the original policy has changed to a larger group of countries
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

The change means that travellers reaching Denmark from these countries must be vaccinated in order to be eligible to enter. Those who have recovered from the Coronavirus in recent months are also eligible to enter. Upon arrival to Denmark, the same must also undergo a second test after entry and stay self-isolated for ten days. description:
Jógvan Skorheim, mayor, and chairman of Norðoya Bú- og Heimatænasta has decided, together with the management of the institutions, to implement comprehensive safety measures that are deemed necessary.
The measures will be implemented on 13 March and will remain in effect until Sunday 29 March.
Child care institutions, Húsið, children’s dental service, and Klaksvík municipality’s after-school recreation center are stopping their activities. If parents/legal guardians need to make use of these services, they are asked to contact the manager in question.

description: From 16 November 2020, the government of Denmark adds mask exemptions in the case that "children and young people or people with mental or physical disabilities for various reasons need to be comforted or are intimidated by the use of a face covering or visor." Those exempt already are: Children under 12, those with a reduced level of consciousness, physical or mental impairments, those that are otherwise unable to wear face mask or visors, and residents/patients of the facility are exempt from the face covering requirement at businesses / private sector locations. The policy is actual until 12 December 2022
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From midnight on the night of Wednesday 10 March 2021, the police can now issue fines on the spot to citizens who do not wear face masks in the area, Vollsmose Parish, Denmark. It thus becomes both a criminal offense not to wear a face mask and a criminal offense for the retail trade to fail to display it. The tightening includes Retail trade, including in select stores, convenience stores, shopping centers, department stores, warehouses, bazaars, arcades, and places that sell food and drinks that are not consumed at the point of sale (take-away), etc. There are several exceptions: the requirement for a mask does not apply to persons with a reduced level of consciousness, physical or mental impairments, or other things that make them unable to wear a mask or visor. The policy is actual until 7 April 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
"Jógvan Skorheim, mayor, and chairman of Norðoya Bú- og Heimatænasta has decided, together with the managements of the institutions, to implement comprehensive safety measures that are deemed necessary.
The measures will be implemented on 13 March and will remain in effect until Sunday 29 March.
Every employee of Klaksvík municipality will work from home. Every employee who was meant to travel abroad in service of the municipality is asked to cancel the trip. People who have been abroad must not come to work. Employees who have been abroad this last week are asked not to come to work in the coming 2 weeks.City hall meetings and committee meetings in March are cancelled "

description: Denmark is enforcing a restriction of mass gatherings:  It became illegal to assemble more than ten people in public after march 18. UPDATE: Now the number of people allowed in public space are only 10, and now it's not volunatry anymore but enforced with fines

Effective March 18, 2020, the Danish government has prohibited groups of more than ten people from gathering in any public space indoors or outdoors. These measures will remain in effect until March 30, 2020. UPDATE: If the police have to dissolve an assembly of more than 10 people, it will trigger a fine of 1,500 kroner per person. Should a person be caught in a crowd with more than 9 others at one time, then the price can rise.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Danes can now hold private summer parties outside the home until later than 24.00, since the government and the parties of the Parliament agreed on 11 June on easing the requirements. Establishments must continue to be closed between 24:00 and 05:00, but will from Saturday, June 13, 2020, after 24.00 for private parties such as weddings, graduation parties, birthdays, and similar events where participants know each other in advance (provided that only people attending the event have access to the dining venue). It will also be possible to hold private parties such as weddings, graduation parties, birthdays and similar events (where participants know each other in advance), in e.g. rented banqueting rooms, assembly halls or the like, if there are more than 50 people present but then it is subject to a requirement that the participants must be seated. The health authorities will issue recommendations and good advice for private events.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As published on July 27 2020, Public events can take place with a maximum of 500 people if they are mainly seated, and a maximum of 100 people gathering in all other cases (whether in a private or public setting). events, activities etc. with more than 100 participants gathering simultaneously at the same location are still banned unless the participants are mainly seated. The ban on gatherings does not extend to professional sports, including the top two male football leagues, the top female football league, the top male handball league, the top female handball league, the top male ice hockey league, the top badminton league, harness races and gallop races at the nine commercial horse racing tracks with licenced drivers and riders as well as other professional branches of sports in which most athletes make a living as athletes. Nor does the ban extend to athletes at senior international level whose primary source of income is their athlete's salary, or who belong to one of the athlete categories of Team Denmark or have been nominated or selected for the Olympic/Paralympic Games.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Denmark is lowering the maximum number of people allowed to assemble, from 100 to 50, in 17 municipalities of the Copenhagen region, along with Odense municipality. This is to combat the recent rising transmission rate of COVID-19 in these places.

description: Mass gatherings decreased to 50 in 18 municipalities in Denmark. On Monday, September 7,2020 the Danish government announced a tightening of restrictions to combat the spread of the coronavirus disease  COVID-19  in eighteen municipalities across the country, with the measures coming into effect on Wednesday, September 9. They include a reduction in the number of people allowed to gather to 50 down from 100. Bars, cafes, and restaurants will also have to close at midnight  local time , having previously been allowed to stay open till 02 00. The restrictions apply Copenhagen, Odense; as well as 16 municipalities in or bordering greater Copenhagen  Frederiksberg, Tarnby, Dragor, Hvidovre, Bronby, Vallensaek, Ishoj, Rodovre, Glostrup, Albertslund, Hoje-Taastrup, Gentofte, Gladsaxe, Ballerup, Herlev, Lyngby-Taarbaekas
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Danish government introduced the ban on small gatherings lowering allowed people number from 50 to 10 people on 23 October 2020. description: Published on 6 February 2021, Events or other activities with more than 5 people gathered simultaneously at the same location are banned. This ban applies to both indoor and outdoor gatherings, and it applies to both public and private events etc. The ban on gatherings of more than five people does not apply to religious ceremonies, including baptism and marriage, performed in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Denmark and other religious communities at premises usually at the disposal of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Denmark or another religious community, whereas the ban on gatherings of more than 500 people simultaneously still applies.

description: Danish government introduced the ban on small gatherings lowering allowed people number from 50 to 10 people on 23 October 2020. The ban will be effective on 26 October and for four weeks onwards. An exception is introduced for sports and association activities for children and young people up to the age of 21, including possibly responsible persons over the age of 21, if this is deemed necessary for the proper conduct of the activity. However, there must be a maximum of 50 people for these activities. UPDATE: UPDATE: Extends order that activities for socially disadvantaged children and young people 21 or younger with or without their families arranged by the public authorities, organizations, associations, companies and cultural institutions remain exempt from the gathering ban and are allowed to have up to 50 people present.

description: Announced on April 21, 2021, the employer must organise the work so that a part of the workforce continues to work from home. The employer must also ensure that there is the required social distancing space (i.e. 2 meters) between those employees who do attend work. For those employees who do attend the workplace, their working hours should be arranged as flexibly as possible to ensure as few employees as possible are using public transportation during rush hours and to minimize the number of employees arriving at work at the any one time. Physical meetings (including courses, business travel, etc.) should be avoided to the greatest extent possible.

description:
From 12 March, the government of Denmark introduced measures to contain the spread of the Covid-19 coronavirus in the Faroe Islands. The measures include

- appealing to organizers to postpone or cancel all events expected to attract more than 100 people.- appealing to people to travel only in cases of high necessity,

description: Measures were first introduced by the March 17th guidelines issued by the Board of Health. These recommended that family members and friends should not visit nursing homes (or hospitals) unless strictly necessary, for instance, if the person was terminally ill. The individual institution should ensure that the visit could be conducted in a safe manner, for instance by ensuring that it was only a brief visit, that visitors did not sit in common areas and that they did not have physical contact or use common facilities. The institution was required to inform visitors about the risk of spreading the disease and encourage them to avoid visiting, through posters (see poster below with the message  ‘You best protect your loved ones by not visiting them’) and personal instruction. If family members had symptoms, they were not allowed to visit. Instead, it was recommended to stay in contact over the telephone, video, or mail.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
The Danish government will temporarily suspend handshakes for constitutional ceremonies from the 16th of April 2020.
Minister of Foreign Affairs and Integration Mattias Tesfaye will suspend the rule that future citizens must lend a hand in connection with them becoming Danish citizens.

description: The National Board of Health of Denmark recomendate for risk groups include to limit situations where one may be exposed to infection. Therefore, a recommendation to avoid places with a lot of people, eg public transport during rush hour is given, as well as to make purchases when or where there are the few other people in the stores. The policy is actual from May 4 to May 15, 2020
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Danish Health Authority recommends wearing a face mask in the following situations: If you are infected or at risk of being infected with novel coronavirus and have to leave your home, for example because you need to be tested. If you are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19 - and you are not fully vaccinated - and get into situations where it is difficult for either you or others to keep a distance of 2 metres apart. If you visit someone at higher risk and whom you do not live with - and who is not fully vaccinated - for example a person in a nursing home or assisted living facility, please consider wearing a face mask in those situations when you cannot keep a distance of at least 2 metres. At large gatherings where it can be difficult to keep your distance.  In situations where close face-to-face contact is unavoidable for 15 minutes or more at a distance of less than 1 metres. The policy is actual from March 4 until March 17, 2021
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People who are partially vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19

description:
On 10 May, the National Board of Health in Denmark issued new health professional recommendations on the prevention of the spread of infection. The recommendations mean that the distance requirement is lowered, and there is a greater focus on good hygiene.
The National Board of Health recommends that you keep a physical distance of 1 meter and especially avoid being close if you are face-to-face. There may be a number of situations where - even over long periods of time - it is not possible to secure at least a 1-meter distance between people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of May 11, 2020 The Danish Health Authority has from the start of the coronavirus pandemic advised the general public against wearing face masks in public, arguing both that the benefits are unproven, and that doing so risks making it more difficult for health authorities to source supplies.   "The Danish Health Authority does not recommend that healthy people who move around in public generally wear face masks," the authority explains in a Question and Answer section on its website.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: A few weeks before 14 April 2020, the public transport partial lockdown of Danish society, the number of passengers using public transport has been down by more than 80 percent. The current timetables for busses, the light rail, trains, and the metro have therefore been downscaled. A consequence of the controlled reopening of society is that the number of passengers will increase. To avoid excessive passenger density, a considerable upscaling of public transport has been made as of Tuesday, 14 April 2020 in Metropolitan Copenhagen in particular. The upscaling will involve more departures and longer trains. Users, schools, and workplaces must also contribute to even use of public transport through flexible planning. Moreover, the increased cleaning frequency on common contact surfaces in public transport means and at stations will remain at the same high level. The policy is actual until 22 August 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
As of May 13, 2020 in Denmark visits are limited to public and private placements such as visit restrictions on nursing homes, relief places as well as hospitals and clinics, housing locations, including retirement homes, women's shelters, and substance abuse treatment centers, and other social emergency services in connection with the handling
of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). Only regular visits from 1-2 permanent visitors are allowed. UPDATE: New executive order from the Ministry of Health and the Elderly eases the previous visit restrictions on e.g. nursing homes and hospitals. The Danish Agency for Patient Safety has therefore today issued new orders.The temporary visit restrictions imply that:
-visits to nursing homes should as far as possible take place in outdoor areas
-residents or patients who, for health reasons or due to the physical environment, cannot receive visits outside, can now have visits indoors by 1-2 regular visitors. UPDATE: New executive order from the Ministry of Health and the Elderly eases the previous visit restrictions on e.g. nursing homes and hospitals. The Danish Agency for Patient Safety has therefore today issued new orders.

description: As a response to the criticism, on April 24th the Board of Health a revised version of the guideline was issued,  emphasizing that the outdoor areas were not included in the ban for visitors. On May 12th an extensive publication providing new guidelines on how to organize visits in nursing homes was published by the Board of Health. From the introduction, it was made clear that the Board of Health did not have the authority over who could visit, as this was the responsibility of the Board for Patient Safety, thus underlining the general confusion over which authority was in charge. The policy is actual until 1 July 2020

description: Denmark will from Thursday, July 2nd, 2020 allow friends and relatives of people in elderly care homes and hospitals to visit as often as they like, in a move some experts have warned is a step too far.  Visitors will be able to meet residents and patients both outside their homes and in their rooms and common spaces.     However, hygiene restrictions as laid out in the specific Health Ministry plans continue to be in place and were subsequently updated July 9th, November 25th, December 7 (version 5&6&7, see source below).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The National Board of Health has updated the general recommendations for how to prevent the spread of infection with new coronavirus. The recommendations now also contain information on the use of face masks in certain situations. On the basis of the WHO s recommendations, the National Board of Health has reassessed the use of masks. The assessment remains that one can generally move in public space without wearing a mask. However, there are some special situations where one can not comply with the general recommendations and where a barrier protection, such as mask, can be used instead. The situations where wearing of mask is now recommended are  If you are infected or have symptoms of COVID-19 and need to break your self-isolation to transport yourself to and from the hospital; If you are on your way home from, for example, the airport after a trip in a high-risk area abroad and need self-isolation; If you are in close contact with someone who is infected and needs to break self-isolation to transport you to and from tests; If you are a relative and cannot keep your distance from a person at increased risk, eg when in need of care and attention.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on July 31, 2020, The Danish Health and Medicines Authority expands its recommendations on the use of face masks in special situations, and now points out that it is advantageous to use a mask if you move out in public transport, at times when it can be difficult to keep your distance from other passengers. Further, in situations such as in a business context where frequent or prolonged face-to-face contact is unavoidable, as well as at large gatherings when prolonged face-to-face contact cannot be avoided, or cannot be prevented with other measures such as distance.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From the 8th of August 2020, Due to the increased spread of infection, the Central Jutland Region has, following an order from the Danish Agency for Patient Safety, reintroduced temporary visit access restrictions at all the region s hospitals. The restrictions apply to both somatic and psychiatric wards and have already been reintroduced at Aarhus University Hospital. The restrictions mean that there can only be one companion or visitor per. patient. All non-hospital staff - including patients, visitors companions, craftsmen and other external people who must enter the hospitals and who do not have a negative COVID test within 72 hours - are encouraged on arrival to wear a sanitary napkin.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

In critical situations, however, one to two permanent visitors may be given special permission to visit a resident inside. Visiting restriction was in effect in Aarhus since the major outbreak.

description: On August 12, 2020, The Minister of Social Affairs of Denmark introduces visit restrictions in Silkeborg. Relatives of residents in social housing in Silkeborg Municipality may only visit their loved ones outdoors due to increasing covid-19 infection in the municipality. In critical situations, however, one to two permanent visitors may be given special permission to visit a resident inside. Visiting restriction was in effect in Aarhus since the major outbreak.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting other group residential facilities (e.g. orphanages; group homes)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: FromAugust 15, 2020, In view of the increasing infection pressure, the Danish Health and Medicines Authority now recommends the use of bandages in public transport throughout the country at all times of the day. When the new executive order enters into force, bandages will be a requirement for driving with public transport, however, certain groups of persons will be exempt, e.g. children. At the same time, we recommend that people at increased risk of severe course of COVID-19 wear a mouthpiece in all situations where it is not possible to keep the recommended distance of two meters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18 August 2020, Denmark's government announced that retirement homes reopen to visitors. However, certain restrictions apply. In the first week, only two relatives are allowed to visit each resident. From next week, up to six people will be allowed to visit each unit of a retirement home, provided that the infection rate goes down even further. Denmark's government reports that the health authorities are asking those planning to visit their elderly relatives to get tested regularly, including before their first visit.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 19 September 2020, the Government of Denmark ruled that customers or other visitors aged 12 and over must have their mouths and noses covered using a mask or visor when they are on premises at catering establishments where food is served, or drinks or tobacco are at sale for consumption. The requirement is in force until 5 October 2020. Children under 12, those with a reduced level of consciousness, physical or mental impairments, or people that are otherwise unable to wear face masks or visors are exempt from this rule. Previously mask requirements were limited to specific regions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 10 October to 26 October 2020, in Denmark, public transport passengers are required to wear face masks or shields.  Airline passengers must wear surgical face masks from the moment they enter a terminal and while on board a flight until they leave the terminal after their arrival  Danish National Police may fine individuals for violating COVID-19 regulations. The fine for failure to wear a face mask, violating gathering limits, or loitering in areas deemed “hotspots” is 2500 Danish Kroner for a first-time offense and can increase thereafter for repeated violations.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 23 October 2021, Bronderslev, Ringkobing-Skjern, Thisted, Frederikshavn, Aalborg, Jammerbugt, and Hjorring received an order from the Danish Agency for Patient Safety to introduce a ban on visits to care centers In the past week, the municipalities have had an incidence rate of over 40. The ban on visits to the municipality s care centers means that visits are generally closed, but that a resident can have a permanent next of kin who is allowed to visit. It is also allowed to visit in critical situations.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Bronderslev, Ringkobing-Skjern, Thisted, Frederikshavn, Aalborg, Jammerbugt, and Hjorring

description: "On 26 October 2020, a definite ban on visitors to all care homes in seven municipalities is now being introduced. These are Ringkøbing-Skjern, Thisted, Brønderslev, Frederikshavn, Aalborg, Jammerbugt, and Hjørring. This is stated by The Danish board for patient safety in a press release. The new ban on visitors means that it is temporarily not allowed to visit nursing homes. Nor in outdoor areas, which have otherwise been permitted in several places despite visitor restrictions. It is still possible for the individual resident to nominate one relative who can pay a visit. Just as it is still possible to visit in critical situations. This applies, for example, if a resident is dying."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: As of Monday, 9 November 2020, students at institutions of higher education in the affected municipalities will move to online teaching and have exams not requiring physical attendance. This also applies to students at institutions of higher education in Aalborg who are resident in the affected municipalities. In exceptional cases, physical attendance may be required. In those situations, everyone is expected to pay close attention to not attend if they have symptoms, to hand hygiene, cleaning, social distancing and to wear a face mask

description: The new guidance on 25th November contains an Expansion of the National Board of Health's general advice and change in the formulation of the main priorities in the prevention of the spread of infection. Addition of a section on airways and ventilation.  Sharpened focus on situations where there is no concrete suspicion of infection with a new coronavirus, including a new section on the use of face protection products in common areas in accordance with temporary legal requirements, as well as the use of face protection products in close contact with the citizen in the citizen's home. The policy is actual until 7 December 2020.

description: Danish Health Authority claims that nursing homes, assisted living facilities, etc., where more than 80% of residents have received the second injection may lift their visitor restrictions.   Social institutions that cater to citizens who belong to a risk group and where more than 80% have received the second injection can now lift the visitor restrictions.    Because staff in these sectors have now been fully vaccinated­ against COVID-19, the recommended distance between staff can in some cases be reduced to 1 meter to allow relevant training, meetings, and small conferences to go ahead.    However, a distance of 2 meters between patients and between staff and patients must be maintained. The guideline was updated on 18 March 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 22, 2021 it was announced that on April 6, 2021 With measures to reduce contagion, study groups and reading groups can meet physically at the educational institutions. In the reopening, guidelines will apply regarding distance, hygiene and requirements for masks, just as the current model for testing is maintained.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education

description: From 16 April 2021, The Danish Health Authority requires that you always keep a distance of at least one meter from others and, if possible, 2 meters. . When singing, shouting, exercising, and in other situations where there is an increased risk of spreading infection, it is still recommended to maintain a distance of at least 2 meters. In addition, people at increased risk of severe COVID-19 are also advised to maintain a distance of at least two meters from others.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of June 14, 2021, Danish government announces that the requirements for face masks / visors will be abolished in the entire area of the Ministry of Children and Education, but the requirement for staff in day care centers and primary schools will not be abolished.
